column1: The original Jeep was the prototype Bantam BRC. Willys MB Jeeps went into production in 1941[1] specifically for the military
column2: arguably making them the oldest four-wheel drive mass-production vehicles now known as SUVs.[4] The Jeep became the primary light 4-wheel-drive vehicle of the United States Army and the Allies during World War II
column3: as well as the postwar period. The term became common worldwide in the wake of the war. Doug Stewart notes:[5]
and unstintingly functional jeep became the ubiquitous World War II four-wheeled personification of Yankee ingenuity and cocky

column1: The first civilian models were produced in 1945.[6] It inspired a number of other light utility vehicles

column1: 4;potatoes;to auchan;200;small text about potatoes;"The potato is a starchy
column2: tuberous crop from the perennial nightshade Solanum tuberosum L. The word ""potato"" may refer either to the plant itself or to the edible tuber.[2] In the Andes
column4: there are some other closely related cultivated potato species. Potatoes were introduced outside the Andes region approximately four centuries ago
column5: [3] and have since become an integral part of much of the worldTs food supply. It is the worldTs fourth-largest food crop

column1: Wild potato species occur throughout the Americas from the United States to southern Chile.[5] The potato was originally believed to have been domesticated independently in multiple locations
column2: [6] but later genetic testing of the wide variety of cultivars and wild species proved a single origin for potatoes in the area of present-day southern Peru and extreme northwestern Bolivia (from a species in the Solanum brevicaule complex)
column5: 000 years ago.[7][8][9] Following centuries of selective breeding
column6: there are now over a thousand different types of potatoes.[8] Over 99% of the presently cultivated potatoes worldwide descended from varieties that originated in the lowlands of south-central Chile
column7: which have displaced formerly popular varieties from the Andean highlands.[10][11]

column2: the local importance of the potato is variable and changing rapidly. It remains an essential crop in Europe (especially eastern and central Europe)
column3: where per capita production is still the highest in the world
column4: but the most rapid expansion over the past few decades has occurred in southern and eastern Asia. As of 2007 China led the world in potato production
column5: and nearly a third of the worldTs potatoes were harvested in China and India.[12]";0

column1: The tomato belongs to the nightshade family
column2: Solanaceae.[1][3] The species originated in the South American Andes[2] and its use as a food originated in Mexico
column3: and spread throughout the world following the Spanish colonization of the Americas. Its many varieties are now widely grown
column4: sometimes in greenhouses in cooler climates.The plants typically grow to 1–3 meters (3–10 ft) in height and have a weak stem that often sprawls over the ground and vines over other plants. It is a perennial in its native habitat
column5: although often grown outdoors in temperate climates as an annual. An average common tomato weighs approximately 100 grams (4 oz)";0
